The Hyken & Costco chairs have the same issues. The mesh on both are cheap and will sink over time and if you sit on them 8+hrs a day they'll be lucky to last you 2 years. (if you're 200+lbs they probably wont last you one year) Another problem is the actual design of both the Hyken & Costco chair.  Look at 12:50 and notice how the Herman Miller has a "V" designed brace in the back that is much larger & spans a bigger length than the Hyken. The Hyken & Costco have a brace that doesn't support the entire back of the chair. Why is this important? Because over time both the back of the Hyken & Costco chair will actually bend where the brace ends, (in the middle) and essentially make it so you can't sit up in the chair at all unless you put a pillow behind your back.  Over time the lack of bracing will also make the chair snap in that location. You can always return/exchange the Costco chair at any time so at least you wont be out money if you buy one of those.

I have the Hyken chair and am 6'2 145 lbs. It's an absolute nightmare for even moderately tall people. First off if you plan on using the headrest, in its stock form, it will dig into your shoulders or even your back. The height seems to be designed for those that fall below 5'8. There are videos on how to mod the headrest, but even with that extra length it still digs into my shoulders forcing me to hunch or slouch beneath it. I am thus forced to use it without the headrest. Now the second problem, the arch support and the curve in the lower back are WAYY too low on my back even at its highest setting, it nearly jabs into my sacrum. This also forces bad posture and pain over even just an hour or two of sitting. The lack of adjustability is a huge negative for me. I did a mod where I slid the seat forward more allowing for a further back and deeper position to alleviate some of the issues with the arch being so low. This made it more comfortable and supports the back and legs better. The armrests are at awkward widths in my case and I usually only rest my left elbow on it as I keep my keyboard off-angle -15 degrees or so for more mouse swing on lower dpi/sens settings. Quality control is also bad as some armrests won't even match each other's levels, one arm will be millimeters lower or taller than the other and the mesh frame will be seated off balance leaving you rotated at a slight angle rather than sitting straight. Overall it's an ok attempt at trying to be a more ergonomic chair, and I would rec it any day over terrible gamer DRX style chairs or executives and any other cheap office chairs on the market, but I regret my purchase and wish I had just put the money towards something better.

Previously, I owned a Serta faux leather garden variety chair I bought from Office Depot and the difference is night and day (granted this is a $2xx chair compared to a $1400 Aeron). But that chair didn't last more than 4 years before the faux leather around the head rest area began to peel and tear and the arm rest was wobbly and required tightening every month and began creaking and squeaking. Sitting on the Aeron has been a life-changing event for me.

When I'm faced with a tight deadline, my favorite chair to use for coding is an old drum throne (chair) that I usually use when playing guitar. Not having a back rest adds a feeling of anxiousness, and it helps me get down to business faster. That, and/or the mesh stretches, frays, and rips, or you're left with cheap gas cylinders that can no longer support the weight of yourself or the chair.    This just leaves you buying yet another chair and throwing $200 into the trash again and again, so before you know it you've spent the equivalent of an Aeron or Gesture on chairs you've had to toss in the garbage. I've found that spending more for a high quality chair is worth it, because the quality is invested and readily apparent in the product from the largest components down to the smallest bolt, and you'll feel the difference when sitting in it at first and for months and years down the road.
